Content_wSideColumn.Abstract: A list of several suggestions for those who are searching for a job.

Content_wSideColumn.BodyCopy:
1. When you graduate with your degree, what specific skill will you have in your possession that an employer will pay you to do?
  2. If you want a job, don't forget the employer's point of view.
  3. Every job has its positives and negatives. Try finding a job where you would feel comfortable.
  4. Try out your future career before you finish your degree by doing an internship or by volunteering. This way you can find out if the job is what you thought it would be.
  5. The three main screen out criteria are:
    • appearance,
    • dependability, and
    • skill.
  6. Getting a job has a lot to do with marketing - and you're the product. Make sure that your materials look professional and that you act in a professional manner.
  7. Do your homework.
  8. A positive first impression is very important.
  9. When conducting a job search, many people act like a gold mine - just waiting to be discovered. Most of the time, employers won't search you out. You need to get out and sell yourself.
  10. Choose a major that you're excited about, yet has a practical application so you can find yourself a job upon completing your schooling.
  11. If you need some help, just ask. Oftentimes, you don't "get" unless you " ask."
  12. Networking is the easiest way to get a job.
  13. Most jobs are never advertised.
  14. Prepare for the interview. If you don't - it is painfully obvious to the employer. Be prepared for common questions.
  15. Don't get too discouraged, searching for a job can be a real challenge, no matter how qualified you are.
  16. Find out what education and experience is necessary to get the job that you want. Then, get to work preparing for that job.
  17. At the present time, what job are you realistically prepared to get? Do you need more education or experience to get the job that you really want?
  18. Generally speaking, the more education and training that you get, the more money you will make.
  19. New jobs will require higher skills - especially computer skills. Technical skills are essential.
  20. Employers want workers with:
    • interpersonal skills,
    • leadership skills,
    • critical thinking skills,
    • decision making skills, and
    • writing and speaking skills.
  21. Go to you nearest career resource center and ask for a list of the "hottest" jobs.
  22. If you are willing to relocate, you will have a much better chance of finding employment. Some cities are faster growing, more economically healthy, and have lower unemployment rates. It is generally easier to find a job in these cities.
  23. Fill out applications completely and very neatly.
  24. Doing a marginal job on your résumé is a good way to get you screened out of a job.
  25. Proof-read everything that you send to an employer.
  26. Ask people before you list them as references on your application or résumé.
  27. An interview is "any contact that you have with someone that has authority to influence the decision as to whether or not you get hired."
  28. Dress for success.
  29. Sell yourself in the interview - yet, don't be too overbearing. Remember, the employer is trying to find someone that he/she can work with.
  30. Be courageous and confident. Look people in the eyes.
  31. Know your own skills and qualities.
